content.user_title: Slack GIF Creator - Animated Emoji & Message GIFs
content.value_statement: Create professional animated GIFs optimized for Slack with automatic size optimization, frame validation, and smooth easing functions that ensure your animations meet platform requirements.
actual_capabilities: Create animated GIFs optimized for Slack's size and dimension requirements (128x128 emoji, 480x480 messages)
Generate frames programmatically using PIL drawing primitives (circles, polygons, stars, gradients, text)
Apply smooth animation easing functions (bounce, elastic, ease-in/out, back, etc.)
Optimize GIF file size through color quantization, duplicate frame removal, and dimension reduction
Validate GIFs against Slack requirements (dimensions, file size, frame count)
Support common animation patterns (shake, pulse, bounce, spin, fade, slide, zoom, particle effects)
Create gradient backgrounds and composite visual elements
limitations: Does not include pre-built graphic assets or emoji fonts
Requires Python with PIL, imageio, and numpy dependencies
Text rendering limited to PIL's default fonts
Cannot render complex emoji characters reliably across platforms
No automatic scene detection or advanced image processing beyond optimization

best_practices: Start with emoji size (128x128) and 10-12 fps for small file sizes - only increase if needed
Use fewer colors (48-64) for emoji GIFs to keep file size under 100KB
Apply easing functions (ease_out, bounce_out) instead of linear motion for professional-looking animations
Enable remove_duplicates=True when saving to eliminate redundant frames
Use thicker lines (width=2 or higher) for shapes and outlines - thin lines look choppy
Add visual depth with gradients, layered shapes, and contrasting colors
Keep emoji GIF duration under 2-3 seconds for better user experience
Validate with is_slack_ready() before considering the GIF complete
Use optimize_for_emoji=True for automatic dimension and color optimization
Test animations at actual size (128x128) to ensure details are visible
anti_patterns: Don't use emoji fonts for graphics - they're unreliable across platforms
Avoid width=1 for lines and outlines - they look amateurish and pixelated
Don't create 30fps animations for Slack - wastes file size with minimal quality improvement
Don't skip validation - always check that GIFs meet Slack requirements before delivery
Avoid plain geometric shapes without depth - add gradients, highlights, or layered elements
Don't assume pre-packaged graphics exist in the skill - generate everything from PIL primitives
Don't optimize prematurely - create the animation first, then optimize if file size is too large
Avoid linear interpolation for all motion - use easing functions for more natural movement

faq.question: What size should my Slack GIF be?
faq.answer: For emoji: 128x128 pixels (recommended). For message GIFs: 480x480 pixels. The skill's optimize_for_emoji=True flag automatically handles emoji sizing.

faq.question: Why is my GIF file size too large?
faq.answer: Reduce frames (use 10fps instead of 20), decrease colors (num_colors=48), enable remove_duplicates=True, or use optimize_for_emoji=True for automatic optimization. Target under 100KB for emoji.

faq.question: Can I use uploaded images in my animations?
faq.answer: Yes! Use PIL's Image.open() to load user-uploaded images. You can animate them directly or use them as reference for colors and style.

faq.question: What animation effects are supported?
faq.answer: Shake/vibrate, pulse/heartbeat, bounce, spin/rotate, fade in/out, slide, zoom, and particle bursts. Combine effects for more complex animations using PIL primitives and easing functions.

faq.question: How do I make animations look more professional?
faq.answer: Use thicker lines (width=2+), add gradients, layer multiple shapes, apply easing functions (not linear), use contrasting colors, and add visual depth with highlights or shadows.

faq.question: What easing functions are available?
faq.answer: linear, ease_in, ease_out, ease_in_out, bounce_in, bounce_out, elastic_in, elastic_out, back_in, back_out, and more. See core.easing for the complete list.
